ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I was under the impression that this class would be more integrative of policy AND science but as a science person, I felt that it was all policy and not catered in a way to interest or involve science people in the policy process. Overall a dull class.
Course is very useful in that through readings and lectures it gives you a broad understanding of what "planning" really is at a professional level.

Nowhere in the class description did it say that this course would have such a strong legal/regulatory bias. The class was very one-sided. Too many of the guest speakers came from the legal field, or from Pace Law directly. I recognize that it is helpful to understand and learn about land use planning from a legal perspective, but it is not always appropriate to have them talk about these issues...Important perspectives that we missed in this class include: technical details and knowledge on energy sprawl and hydraulic fracturing, specific project management perspectives on urban land use projects, scientific understanding of effects on ecosystems (water, wildlife, etc.).
There should be some New Haven oriented topics, guest lecture, site visits, field trips.
the field trip was the best part of the course- wish there had been more!
I really liked attending the Pace Law conference.
Question 1: No one read any of the readings in this class.
I enjoyed the guest lectures very much.
The class should have had a broader emphasis on international issues and aspects around land use and planning.
Ques. 7: The professor did a great job of putting together a roster of interesting speakers representing a wide range of professional applications of land use law, planning, design, etc.

Overall the course did not meet my expectations in terms of content. It should be addressed at the beginning that this course is most interesting or appropriate for law students. While some of the lectures (e.g. fracking, shrinking cities) were very informative, most of the lectures would have been more valuable if the lecturers had focused on conveying a mix of background information and possible solutions. With regard to solutions it would be much more interesting if they were discussed from a regular practitioners point of view rather than from a legal standpoint.
Getting to hear a different person speak every week.
A few of the guest lecturers were great.
The speaker about energy sprawl and the Pace Conference.
Different perspectives on land use

The field trip and the guest lectures. I think this is an excellent 1-credit introductory course to land use planning. I do wish there were more options throughout the school even though Yale does not have a planning school. Most environmental managers will have to deal with the planning process. A course on environmental dispute resolution or negotiations would also be just as helpful in the curriculum, but this should be a more substantial course.I also think Professor Nolon did an excellent job of covering so many different land use topics and brought something for everyone in environmental management.
Uma Outka's lecture on the energy-land use nexus.
the Pace land use center conference
The participation in the conference at Pace Law School.
Variety of speakers and perspectives.

Professor Nolon was the best part of the course. He was extremely knowledgeable and was an engaging speaker. I wish we could have had more lectures where he was the presenter. I also liked how the course covered a variety of topics which allowed students to get a taste of what's out there so that they could take future classes in areas they found interesting. The field trip was also really interesting.
It was easy and you could pay attention when you wanted to pay attention.
I thought the exposure to a wide variety of topics in the land use planning field was excellent.
The first and second to last lecture. And, the opportunity to attend the Land Use Conference, where the two key note speakers were excellent.
Guest speakers and industry interaction
John Nolan!! I wish he lectured more often!
The diversity of topics covered
The professor seemed inspired with the possibilities of planning and land use law, for a sustainable society,and he conveyed this in his presentations.
The hydrofracking talk and the collaborative development talk.
The first lecture on shrinking cities was by far the most engaging. Also, I very much enjoyed the conference at Pace University.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Speakers should come from more diverse career/field/sector backgrounds.
Some of the speakers assumed a knowledge of legal issues and statutes associated with planning. This was confusing at times.
Needs more integration/connection between different concepts and speakers.

Have the course in a different classroom. It's a seminar and there was very little opportunity for discussion. I know the presenters only had an hour to cover such broad topics, but it would have been a little better to have more time for question and answer each class session.
see note about New Haven field trips. make at least part of this class place-based so we can witness some decision making, planning, and implementation.
more question and answer period with each of the speakers
Readings and speakers with international outlook.
Some speakers were really dull and poor presenters.

The speakers. The first and last speaker were great, but overall, the speakers were not engaging. I realize that giving presentations is not easy, but one presenter just read off of a sheet. Students in the audience would just open up their lap tops and zone out until the end of class. More interesting presentations and engaging speakers would have been great.
There were some less interesting lectures and on the whole the classes did not overlap very well.
I enjoyed everything about the course.
There were multiple speakers who were downright boring.
Broaden the scope to include international issues
The quality of lecturers was a little hit-or-miss. Some were fantastic and others were just average.
Not much at all needs improvement.
I would like to see more cohesive lectures. The lecture on LEED ND should be delivered by someone else.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA was fairly non-responsive to questions and the technique of communicating to the class through classes v2 was very easy to mistake for a "new resources posted" message of which several were sent out weekly.
I did not contact either party for help.
Matty was very responsive to questions and comments, did a great job.
Both were very available and helpful.
They were both very available, but I don't think I needed to contact them for very much except topics I was interested in discussing further.
Matty is great--so organized and such a great communicator.
Seemed fine.
Matty did a great job. I really appreciated how organized and responsive he was.
Fine.
They were always available for help.
AVailable when contacted.
Good
TA - Matthew Goldstein was very professional and always extremely helpful.
Matty, TA, was excellent, very accessible to students
Always available to help.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am interested in land-use planning and this course gives a great overview of what the profession consists of.
This was a great introductory course to land use planning and I hope that it strikes more interest among FES students to get more of a core curriculum going.
Great intro to Land Use/Urban Planning.

This is a great course for anyone who is interested in land planning. I do not have a background in land planning and I felt like this course was a great overview of many of the different aspects of land planning.
I am interested in land use planning.

It is interesting to see how land use planning is done to prepare for sea level rise and other climate-related issues. I am also very interested in land use planning to help with watershed management skills.
Land use planning fits into every field and is an interesting topic to consider.
This course does not directly fit into my area of study, but it's a good subject with which to be familiar for environmental policymakers.
Useful to offer a 1 credit course for students interested in Land Use, this was a great intro for me, I hope to take more classes.

Solving complex socioeconomic problems requires that the pattern of governance we make for ourselves fits our stated needs. It's surprising how poor a fit we design sometimes. This course provides tools to improve this design (and that's what my overall program at FES is about)

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about the planning profession.
Planning is directly related to our impact on the environment.
Wanted an intro into land use topics
An introduction to land use planning and to hear from experts in the field. One of the speakers provoked an interest in a research topic for another course I am taking this semester.
interesting design, opportunity to gain from insights of a wide variety of speakers...
I light course for an introduction to land use planning.
I wanted to get an overview of some of the different aspects of land planning.
For the one credit and I am interested in land use planning.
I wanted to learn more about the breadth of issues involved in land use planning in order to better manage watersheds in the future.
To hear a variety of different presenters discuss land use planning.
To gain a better understanding of issues related to land in densely populated urban areas
Interested in gaining a background in current land use planning issues and solutions.
Interest in the topic, hoping to learn more about other courses in this concentration
See question above
Some of the lectures looked interesting and it wasn't a hefty workload

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No. See previous comment.
Yes
It was not as engaging as I'd hoped. I'd give the speakers mixed reviews.
Yes.
yes
yes, although some of the speakers were much more interesting than others...
Somewhat. It is too US focused and the discussion assumes a legal background or interest - I have neither.
Yes
No. I was incredibly disappointed in the class.
Yes.
Yes, it certainly did.
Below expectations. The first outside speaker was so great, followed my mediocrity.
Partly
Yes, but I wish there was a better way to engage students in the reading/class discussion.
YES!
Yes, it more than lived up to expectations.
Mostly no.
No. I was hoping from a more comprehensive introduction to land use planning.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No. See previous comment.
Yes
I thought it would be a more comprehensive, clear approach but the guest speakers felt fragmented.
Yes.
yes
yes.
Some classes were useful and the conference was great.
Yes
I expected more from this class. I really thought there would be more interesting and engaging speakers.
Yes.
Yes, I did very much so.
yes.
As it relates to the east coast of the US. Course should build in a broader scope
Yes
Yes
I got more benefit than I expected

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: n/a
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't take this course unless a) you are particularly interested in the legal/regulatory aspect of land use planning, or b) the guest speaker list is diversified.
If you are interested in international land use you might reconsider. At the same time for a one credit course there's still enough to gain from the limited investment of time.
The work/time commitment required for this class is minimal and the subject matter is incredibly interesting. However the majority of the speakers are not interesting or engaging.
You get out of it what you put into it.
I would recommend listening intently to the lectures and completing all of the readings, as they are all fantastic.
Do your write up early, so you don't have to worry about it the rest of the semester.
Good course to take to gain access to industry experts and opportunities to network
Take advantage of the opportunity to meet with the visiting lecturers.
Attend some of the conversation sessions after the guest speakers presentations. Read the assigned material, even though you may not be held responsible for it.
It's not a big work commitment, and some of the presentations are very interesting. But a lot of students spent most of the class watching the clock and catching up on emails.
